page.title: 17The Village of Scotton
page.content: A compact village with most farms within the main settlement,Scotton has a complex road pattern with no obvious main street or through road.Enclosure came late (1882-84) and the roads and farm lanes retain the sinuous lines of the Medieval landscape,as do hedges - many now gone - shown on an old field map.The church,at the highest point of the village,dates from{12C.}Bungalows stand on the sites of former chapels in Eastgate and Crapple Lane and of the Meeting Room.This was later used as the Church Hall and stood opposite the{former school}in Eastgate.Manor Farm,High Street and Glebe House,East- gate (a privately run residential home for the elderly) are both{Victorian.} More than 60 of the 100 houses are more than 25 years old.There are 2 Grade II listed buildings;St.Genewys Church and 19C Acacia Cottage.
